results.title: This Automation age
results.brief_description: An explanation and history of automation and the benefits and problems it can bring. Animated techniques are used to explain the meaning of automation, and the film illustrates its application in different walks of life.

results.title: This'll do me
results.brief_description: Scenes showing the manufacture and use of fibrous plaster products are used to illustrate the various opportunities for employment in the fibrous plaster industry. Shows the manufacture of plaster sheet and cornice moulds and also the making by hand of moulds for commemorative plaques, complicated patterns used in interior design, window display modellings and other materials requiring the work of skilled artists.

results.title: Thirty million letters
results.creator_credit: Edgar H. Anstey, British Transport Films, General Post Office and James Ritchie
results.brief_description: Every night in Britain, thirty million letters go through the post. This film shows the processes behind the safe delivery of this mail with emphasis on the travelling post office, and sorting, transport and delivery from Euston Station. The film also sees the service from the postman’s point of view, whether at work in the Outer Hebrides or on a daily round in London.

results.title: Thirty-six weeks behaviour day
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Arnold Gesell
results.brief_description: The infant boy whose behaviour day at 12 weeks was charted is now 36 weeks old. His reactions are compared with those which he experienced 24 weeks earlier. His responses to the ministrations of his father and mother are commented upon. The very first successful crawling efforts are observed.

results.title: Thirsty season
results.creator_credit: Richard Davis, Laughing Kookaburra Productions, Traffic Accident Research Unit and Jan Sharp
results.brief_description: Deals with the making of a beer commercial. Raises issues about the influence of the mass media on community attitudes, and the way in which this beer advertisement is structured to create preferences for a particular brand.

results.title: Thirsty land
results.creator_credit: Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, World Food Program and Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
results.brief_description: Describes the search for water in the deserts of Jordan, and other UN assisted works - the training of the Bedouin in farming techniques, the reclamation of land, irrigation, improvement of communications and reafforestation.

results.title: Third world cop [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Carolyn Pfeiffer, Palm Pictures, Island Jamaica Films, Hawk's Nest Productions and Christopher Browne
results.brief_description: Filmed on location in the raw and gritty back streets of modern day Kingston, Jamaica, this action-packed cop thriller tells the story of two friends whose lives have taken them in very different directions. Crime fighter Capone (Paul Campbell) is transferred back to his hometown where he encounters his long time friend Ratty (Mark Danvers) who not only is the right-hand man of the notorious local don, Wonie (Carl Bradshaw), but is also involved in gun-smuggling. Each tries to convince the other to change sides grimly putting their loyalty to one another to the test. But it is their friendship, however, which unfortunately suffers, finally ending in tragic and violent circumstances. “Third world cop” has many classic, sometimes corny, one-liners and is accompanied by a cool laid back soundtrack (produced by Sly & Robbie) of some great reggae and dancehall music performed by Sly & Robbie, Beenie Man, Luciano, Marley Brothers Featuring Ghetto Youths Crew, Lady G, Red Dragon among others. The film, a huge hit in Jamaica and becoming that country’s highest grossing film of all time also features many of the same production team that created “Dancehall queen” (1997), including actor Audrey Reid who plays Capone’s childhood sweetheart, Rita. Cast also includes Winston Bell, Lenford Salmon, Desmond Ballentine aka Ninjaman with cinematography by Richard Lannaman. In English but also contains English subtitles intermittently throughout.

results.title: Third dimension
results.brief_description: In this survey of modern Canadian sculpture, man’s desire to give a third-dimensional form to his image is seen both in the child’s mudpies and in the greatest commemorative monuments. Techniques of the sculptor’s art - carving in wood and stone, clay modelling, making a plaster mold for metal casting - are demonstrated by leading Canadian sculptors, in a survey which extends from totem poles and early French woodcarving to the great war memorial on Vimy Ridge. Included are Jacobine Jones, Frances Loring, Donald Stewart, Louis Parent and Dora Weschler, as well as Emmanuel Hahn with his designs for coins.
